did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: William Miller Abrahams Papers,

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Stanford University. Libraries. Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], William Miller Abrahams Papers, M1125, Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: A poet and a novelist, William Abrahams became one of the leading literary editors in the American publishing scene. He worked with many renowned writers including Joyce Carol Oates, Lillian Hellman, Diane Johnson, Brian Moore, Thomas Flanagan, and Pauline Kael. Beginning as a poet, Abrahams released his first novel Interval in Carolina (1945) to good reviews. He followed with By the Beautiful Sea (1947) and Imperial Waltz (1954) before beginning a career in editing for Atlantic Monthly Press in 1963. In 1965 he began supervising the O. Henry Awards, editing annual anthologies of the best entries, which he continued until his retirement in 1996. Abrahams also produced four non-fiction works that he co-authored with historian Peter Stansky, Journey to the Frontier; Two Roads to the Spanish Civil War (1966), The Unknown Orwell (1972), Orwell: The Transformation (1980), and London's Burning: Life, Death, and Art in the Second World War (1994).

In addition to his editorial career, Abrahams also served as a trustee for the Lillian Hellman-Dashiell Hammett Literary Estates, and as a member of the William Saroyan Foundation. Abrahams' longstanding relationship with Hellman as both editor and friend, subsequently led to his being named official biographer for Hellman in 1983. Abrahams worked sporadically on the Hellman biography until his death in 1998, never reaching completion due to his extensive editorial commitments and deteriorating health.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The William Abrahams Papers include material on books that Abrahams edited under his own imprint for such presses as the Atlantic Monthly Press, Holt Rhinehart and Winston, and E. P. Dutton. The papers contain working drafts, typescripts, research notes, and correspondence. Financial reports and correspondence relating to his service as literary trustee are also present, along with research files on both Lillian Hellman and Dashiell Hammett. Additionally, a collection of the books Abrahams edited during his distinguished career, and the texts he co-authored with historian Peter Stansky are available.
The papers are divided into 4 series: 1. Editorial Files, 2. Trustee Files, 3. Hellman Biography Material, 4. Personal Files.

Wherever Abrahams' original arrangement of materials was encountered, the order was retained. A substantial amount of the material, however, showed little sign of a concise intellectual schema, and therefore required an imposed order. Where possible, arrangement notes for the specific series will indicate which portions retain Abrahams' original arrangement and which reflect an ordering imposed by the processor.

did.unittitle: Series 1. Editorial files

arrangement.p: Within the Editorial Series, the Author files subseries is arranged in alphabetical order, with typescript material, correspondence, editorial material, and book reviews gathered separately within the folders. Abrahams generally bundled all material indiscriminately within large brown envelopes labeled by author and book, possibly after an editorial project was completed. The current arrangement represents a minimal attempt to impose an order where none was apparent. Typescript material may be original or photocopied, full or partial drafts, galleys, or proofs. Correspondence typically contains exchanges between the author, the author's agent, and Abrahams. Editorial material can consist of internal publishing company memorandums, sample pages, proof photographs of author, book jacket samples or proofs, lists of editorial changes, research notes, and other material related to the editing process. Book reviews are typically photocopied, and other photocopied articles concerning the author or book may be included here. The Correspondence subseries generally follows the order imposed by Abrahams, with the exception of letters found mixed in with other unrelated material being added to the files in proper chronological and alphabetical order.

Series 2. Trustee files

scopecontent.p: The Trustee Series is comprised of two subseries, the Hellman-Hammett Literary Trusts, and the William Saroyan Foundation. Both contain correspondence files arranged in chronological order, with the Hellman-Hammett subseries also holding financial statements of the trusts in chronological order. In addition, the Saroyan files have photocopied newspaper and magazine articles concerning Saroyan or the Foundation. The correspondence files for both subseries retain Abraham's original order, while the Hellman-Hammett financial statements are arranged by the processor.

Series 3. Hellman Biography files

scopecontent.p: The Hellman Biography Materials Series had little or no organization, the materials often mixed in with the Hellman-Hammett Trusts materials, but hand-labeled as research. The files are generally divided with Hellman material appearing first, and Hammett material following. The material consists of correspondence between Abrahams and other researchers, typescripts and photocopies of published and unpublished Hellman or Hammett works, photocopies of Hellman or Hammett correspondence, photocopied transcripts of interviews with Hellman, and photocopied newspaper and magazine articles regarding Hellman or Hammett. Please note that original Hellman correspondence may also appear within the Editorial Files Series in both subseries, to retain Abrahams' original order.

Series 4. Personal papers

scopecontent.p: The Personal Series contains some personal and business correspondence regarding the published works of Abrahams and his collaborative efforts with Peter Stansky, typescript of an unpublished poem and novel, legal papers, and personal effects.

did.unittitle: Contracts: Interval in Carolina, 1945, 1946, By the beautiful sea, 1947, Children of Capricorn, 1961
